item.title: Personalizing Haptic Feedback via Uncertainty-Aware Preference Learning
item.description:
Abstract

Personalizing haptic feedback is challenging because users struggle to provide absolute ratings of satisfaction. We propose a preference-based approach that infers a user’s latent utility from binary pairwise comparisons (A/B choices). A Gaussian Process (GP) preference model captures uncertainty and smoothness over the stimulus space, and an active query policy selects comparisons by maximizing expected information gain. Self-reported response uncertainty is incorporated as per-comparison weights, reducing the impact of ambiguous judgments. To mitigate user fatigue and rating drift associated with extensive absolute scoring—and to address the difficulty of placing tactile sensations on a numeric scale—the system emphasizes relative judgments. We implement the method by adapting an existing algorithmic framework to the haptic setting, specifying the GP prior/kernel and an information-gain acquisition function for this domain. Simulations with synthetic ground-truth preferences indicate accurate recovery of preference maps and optima, with improved sample efficiency over uniform sampling.

Our contributions are: (i) a binary, preference-driven alternative to absolute rating for haptic personalization; (ii) an uncertainty-aware GP formulation for pairwise preference learning; and (iii) an active query strategy adapted to haptics and validated in simulation.
